thread.title: T'is the season to be... busy: Top New Year's resolutions for business success

author: Adam Gray
title: T'is the season to be... busy: Top New Year's resolutions for business success
text:
Alison Hall, partner at Hay & Kilner Law Firm (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) Share Get daily   
As we prepare ourselves for Christmas and the New Year, I hope you have received your Basic Payment and you’re ready for the festive season. 
There has been plenty to do in the legal world and my farming clients have been inundated with preparations for winter. 
I am not one for New Year’s resolutions but with 2018 nearly upon us I find myself considering what activities might make the list of things to do next year. 
Here are a few suggestions that might make your list for 2018: 1) Business plan 
Whether it is evaluating your financial structure, investing in marketing, ensuring you’re up to date with recent compliance rules or considering succession planning, updating or starting a business plan should be one of your resolutions. 2) Formalise your business structure 
I am sure many of you have been faced by a solicitor, who looks on in horror, as you explain the informal business arrangement with family. 
There is reason behind the concern – most agricultural solicitors have seen the problems for a farm which can be caused by arguments, retirements, divorces and changes in family circumstances. 
Whether you choose to formalise a family partnership, review your articles of association or change your business structure entirely, formalising any arrangement should certainly make the list for 2018. 3) Review your property portfolio 
If you’re renting properties review your tenancy agreements and make sure you have the right agreement in place to protect you. 
The new year is also a good time to consider the condition of properties, ensure the structure is sound and that fire alarms and carbon monoxide detectors are checked. 
The review of agreements does not end with tenancies, if you rent land or benefit from informal grazing agreements, it might be time to formalise those arrangements. 4) Look after your staff 
Do your employees have employment contracts and are these up to date? 
Are you up to speed with minimum rates of pay, paid holiday requirements and minimum break requirements? 
The New Year is not just a time to review those contracts but it is also a good time to communicate with staff and ensure the smooth operation of your work force. 5) Fight your corner 
As the UK prepares to leave the European Union, it is an important time for the agricultural community in terms of future trade agreements, regulations, staff recruitment and financial support/incentives. 
Whatever your views on Brexit, 2018 is a time to express those views and be part of shaping the UK’s future farming industry. 
Whatever you do decide to do with 2018, at least these jobs can wait until the new year so I will take this opportunity to wish you a very Merry Christmas.
